title: Babies living with abusive parents under CCTV surveillance to be “continually monitored”, watchdog says
text:
Previously councils and the courts could allocate a family to the centres - which are monitored with 24-hour CCTV - when there are serious concerns regarding parenting skills.

They help provide evidence of competence and can play an important role in making difficult long term decisions regarding vulnerable children.

However the new guidance says that only a judge can be responsible for sending families to the residential centres where there is CCTV. It says that: “The use of surveillance in children’s homes and residential family centres is only permissible at the direction of a court to safeguard an individual child’s welfare.”

It adds that any CCTV footage must be “continually monitored” in order to safeguard children. The new guidance states: “When CCTV or audio monitoring is used for the protection of children, plans must include how enough staff will be available to continually monitor images and to take immediate action to safeguard children without reducing the quality of care provided in the home.”

Ofsted said that changes have been made to clarify on which settings are covered by regulation and which by best practice principles.

Following the publication of the new guidance yesterday [FRI], the Children’s Commissioner said: “This is a welcome clarification and given the specific circumstances of the cases the Telegraph raised with us, it is clear in issuing fresh guidelines on the use of CCTV in these settings the government has taken seriously some of the concerns raised this summer.”

An Ofsted spokeswoman said: There has been no change in the law or in Ofsted’s approach to inspecting surveillance in children's social care. However, based on feedback from the social care sector – from children’s homes managers, for example - we wanted our guidance to be clearer about what inspectors want to know when they ask providers about their use of CCTV.”
description: Babies living with abusive parents under CCTV surveillance must be “continually monitored”, a watchdog has said following a Telegraph expose.
